SubTopics: Form, Structure, and Sense, for which students must edit text to conform to conventional usage (e.g., agreement, verb tense/aspect).
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L1 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice repeats the idea of “frequently” and is unnecessary in the sentence.
This choice repeats the idea of “frequently” and is unnecessary in the sentence.
This choice repeats the idea of “frequently” and is unnecessary in the sentence.
Since “frequently” and “many times” repeat the same idea, “many times” can be deleted without changing the meaning of the sentence.

SubTopics: Form, Structure, and Sense, for which students must edit text to conform to conventional usage (e.g., agreement, verb tense/aspect).
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L2 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: The noun “effect” is needed in the sentence to provide a direct object for the verb “has.” Furthermore, the article “a” indicates that a noun will follow. In this sentence the noun “effect” is used to suggest a positive influence. The preposition “on” is idiomatic when used with “effect.”
“Affect” is a verb and the noun “effect” is needed in the sentence. (There is also the noun “affect,” but it means a “display of emotion” and is not appropriate in this context.)
The preposition “to” is not idiomatic in this context.
A noun is needed, not the verb “affects.”

SubTopics: Form, Structure, and Sense, for which students must edit text to conform to conventional usage (e.g., agreement, verb tense/aspect).
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L3 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not create parallel structure in the sentence.
The participle “creating” is consistent with “serving” and “showing,” the other participles in the sentence, and provides parallel structure in the sentence.
This choice does not create parallel structure in the sentence.
This choice does not create parallel structure in the sentence.

SubTopics: Boundaries, for which students must edit text to ensure that sentences are conventionally complete.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L4 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: The comma between “Telescope” and the conjunction “and” correctly separates the series of projects listed in the sentence.
There is no reason to use a semicolon in the sentence.
There is no reason to use a semicolon in the sentence. When listing a series of items in a sentence, punctuation should be placed before the conjunction.
When listing a series of items in a sentence, punctuation should be placed before the conjunction.

SubTopics: Rhetorical Synthesis, for which students must strategically integrate provided information and ideas on a topic to form an effective sentence achieving a specified rhetorical aim.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L5 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively sets up the list of examples that follows in the next sentence?

Key.Rationale: This choice mentions “international cooperation”; however, the sentence that follows lists examples of technology.

B.Choice: garnered national publicity for the agency.

Key.Rationale: This choice mentions “national publicity”; however, the sentence that follows lists examples of technology.

C.Choice: generated a steady stream of new technology.

Key.Rationale: This choice most effectively sets up the list of examples of new technology that are listed in the sentence that follows: “communications satellites, invisible braces, and cordless tools.”

D.Choice: made a lot of money for the agency.

Key.Rationale: This choice mentions “money for the agency”; however, the sentence that follows lists examples of technology.

SubTopics: Form, Structure, and Sense, for which students must edit text to conform to conventional usage (e.g., agreement, verb tense/aspect).
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L6 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not clearly convey the idea that NASA created the inventions.
This choice does not clearly convey the idea that NASA created the inventions.
This option makes the most sense within the context of the paragraph. The inventions listed in the sentence were created or “developed” by NASA.
This choice does not clearly convey the idea that NASA created the inventions.

SubTopics: Form, Structure, and Sense, for which students must edit text to conform to conventional usage (e.g., agreement, verb tense/aspect).
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L7 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: The present tense verb “spawns” is inconsistent with the past tense verbs in the paragraph.
The past tense verb “spawned” is consistent with the other past tense verbs in the paragraph.
The helping verb “has” is not needed since the action took place in the past.
The sentence needs a simple verb to create a complete sentence, and the participle “spawning” doesn't provide that.

SubTopics: Form, Structure, and Sense, for which students must edit text to conform to conventional usage (e.g., agreement, verb tense/aspect).
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L8 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: The participle “coming” would result in a sentence fragment and not a complete sentence in this context.
The relative clause that begins “which came” would result in a sentence fragment and not a complete sentence in this context.
The infinitive phrase “to come” would result in a sentence fragment and not a complete sentence in this context.
The contribution of money occurred in 2005, so the simple past tense verb “came” makes the most sense in the sentence. It also acts as a main verb, which creates a complete sentence.

SubTopics: Transitions, for which students must determine the most effective transition word or phrase to logically connect information and ideas in a text.
Content: Refer to location L9 of the passage and think about the passage as a whole.
To make the third paragraph most logical, sentence 1 should be placed

Key.Rationale: Leaving the sentence where it is now makes the paragraph logical. Sentence 1 serves as a topic sentence for the paragraph by introducing the idea that NASA contributed a significant amount of money to the economy in 2005. The supporting sentences that follow develop the topic sentence by explaining why the benefits of the NASA funding are significant.
If sentence 1 were to be placed after any other sentence, the paragraph would not be logical and would therefore be confusing.
If sentence 1 were to be placed after any other sentence, the paragraph would not be logical and would therefore be confusing.
If sentence 1 were to be placed after any other sentence, the paragraph would not be logical and would therefore be confusing.

SubTopics: Rhetorical Synthesis, for which students must strategically integrate provided information and ideas on a topic to form an effective sentence achieving a specified rhetorical aim.
Content: Refer to location L10 of the passage and think about the passage as a whole.
At this point, the writer is considering adding the following sentence.
:ibox:In addition, NASA has facilities in Washington, DC, Florida, Texas, California, and other states.
Should the writer make this addition here?

A.Choice: Yes, because it serves as a counterargument to the quotation from astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson.

Key.Rationale: The sentence should not be added.

B.Choice: Yes, because it reinforces the passage's point about the importance of NASA's work.

Key.Rationale: The sentence should not be added.

C.Choice: No, because it undermines the passage's claim about the economic benefits of NASA's work.

Key.Rationale: The information it contains is not true. A statement about the locations of various NASA facilities does not undermine the claim about the economic benefits of NASA's work.

D.Choice: No, because it blurs the paragraph's focus by introducing information that does not support the paragraph's claim about the importance of NASA's work.

Key.Rationale: The sentence should not be added because the information it contains — the locations of various NASA facilities — is not relevant to the claim about the importance of NASA's work.

SubTopics: Transitions, for which students must determine the most effective transition word or phrase to logically connect information and ideas in a text.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L11 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: “Therefore” conveys the true relationship between the previous sentence and the statement that follows by indicating that, in addition to the practical benefits it contributes to the economy and society, NASA needs to be supported for global reasons as well.
The transitional word “instead” would change the meaning of the sentence and do not convey the idea that a result or reason will follow.
The transitional words “for example” would change the meaning of the sentence and do not convey the idea that a result or reason will follow.
The transitional word “however” would change the meaning of the sentence and do not convey the idea that a result or reason will follow.

SubTopics: Form, Structure, and Sense, for which students must edit text to conform to conventional usage (e.g., agreement, verb tense/aspect).
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L1 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice contains words that are unnecessary and interrupt the flow of the sentence.
This choice contains words that are unnecessary and interrupt the flow of the sentence.
This choice contains words that are unnecessary and interrupt the flow of the sentence.

This choice is clear and concise and provides parallel structure in the sentence. This choice eliminates unnecessary words and creates a list in which the topics “theories,” “practices,” and “technologies” are equally important.

SubTopics: Boundaries, for which students must edit text to ensure that sentences are conventionally complete.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L2 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice provides an incorrect punctuation mark.
This choice does not provide a comma.
A pair of commas is needed to set off the phrase “from social services to manufacturing” to indicate that this information is explanatory but not crucial for understanding the sentence.
This choice provides an incorrect punctuation mark.

SubTopics: Transitions, for which students must determine the most effective transition word or phrase to logically connect information and ideas in a text.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L3 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: The adverb “accordingly” indicates correctly that because professional development provides a joint benefit to employers and employees, both parties share a joint responsibility to take advantage of the opportunities offered.
This choice provides a transition that does not indicate the true relationship of shared responsibility between employees and employers.
This choice provides a transition that does not indicate the true relationship of shared responsibility between employees and employers.
This choice provides a transition that does not indicate the true relationship of shared responsibility between employees and employers.

SubTopics: Rhetorical Synthesis, for which students must strategically integrate provided information and ideas on a topic to form an effective sentence achieving a specified rhetorical aim.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L4 of the passage.
Which revision best establishes the argument that follows?

Key.Rationale: This choice does not provide an argument for what must happen if employees find themselves “falling behind in the workplace.”

B.Choice: should lean heavily on their employers.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not provide an argument for what must happen if employees find themselves “falling behind in the workplace.”

C.Choice: must be in charge of their own careers.

Key.Rationale: Employees “must be in charge of their own careers.” This claim provides an argument for what follows — “it is the duty of ... employees to identify ... resources” should they find themselves “falling behind in the workplace” — and supports the previous statement about shared responsibility, as well.

D.Choice: will be ready for changes in the job market.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not provide an argument for what must happen if employees find themselves “falling behind in the workplace.”

SubTopics: Boundaries, for which students must edit text to ensure that sentences are conventionally complete.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L5 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: The dependent clause needs to be attached to an independent clause.
A semicolon would be correct in this context only if it were connecting two independent clauses.
There is no comma between the dependent and independent clauses.

A comma is needed between the dependent and independent clauses in order to create one sentence. The introductory conditional dependent clause beginning with “if” cannot stand alone and needs to be separated from the independent clause by a comma.

SubTopics: Rhetorical Synthesis, for which students must strategically integrate provided information and ideas on a topic to form an effective sentence achieving a specified rhetorical aim.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L6 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice is wordy and repeats previously stated ideas.
It provides a clear and concise sentence that doesn't repeat ideas and specifically focuses on workers' “deficiencies.”

C.Choice: deal with their flaws and shortcomings.

Key.Rationale: This choice uses the casual expression “deal with,” which is not the appropriate tone for the passage, and “flaws and shortcomings” mean the same thing.

D.Choice: allow them to meet their employers' needs in terms of the knowledge they are supposed to have.

Key.Rationale: This choice is wordy and repeats previously stated ideas.

SubTopics: Rhetorical Synthesis, for which students must strategically integrate provided information and ideas on a topic to form an effective sentence achieving a specified rhetorical aim.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L7 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice is either not clear or conveys a tone that is inappropriate for the passage.
This choice is either not clear or conveys a tone that is inappropriate for the passage.
“Obsolete” clearly and concisely conveys the idea that skills can become outdated.
This choice is either not clear or conveys a tone that is inappropriate for the passage.

SubTopics: Form, Structure, and Sense, for which students must edit text to conform to conventional usage (e.g., agreement, verb tense/aspect).
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L8 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: The singular verb “includes” does not agree in number with the plural noun “forms.”
“Include” is a plural, present tense verb that agrees in number with the plural noun “forms” and the other present tense verbs in the paragraph.
A simple present tense verb is needed to provide a predicate for the sentence. The participle “including” doesn't provide a predicate.
The present perfect verb form is inconsistent with the present tense verbs in the paragraph.

SubTopics: Transitions, for which students must determine the most effective transition word or phrase to logically connect information and ideas in a text.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L9 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: In addition to the fact that no transition is needed, this choice is incorrect because “around the same time” indicates that time has been discussed earlier in the passage, but it hasn't.
This choice incorrectly indicates that additional information will be added to the previous statement.
This choice wrongly indicates that regardless of what has been said already, what follows is true.

D.Choice: DELETE the emphasized portion and begin the sentence with a capital letter.

Key.Rationale: No transitional link is needed between the two sentences.

SubTopics: Rhetorical Synthesis, for which students must strategically integrate provided information and ideas on a topic to form an effective sentence achieving a specified rhetorical aim.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L10 of the passage.
Which revision makes the writer's description of the figure most accurate?

Key.Rationale: As shown in the illustration, “coaching and consultation” and “foundation and skill-building workshops” occupy smaller circles within the professional-development framework, and thus cannot be the overarching framework.

B.Choice: participation in foundation and skill-building workshops is the overarching framework within which staff receive coaching and consultation as well as the opportunity to belong to a professional network.

Key.Rationale: As shown in the illustration, “coaching and consultation” and “foundation and skill-building workshops” occupy smaller circles within the professional-development framework, and thus cannot be the overarching framework.

C.Choice: membership in a professional network is the overarching framework within which staff receive coaching and consultation as well as the opportunity to attend foundation and skill-building workshops.

Key.Rationale: Since “professional networks” is the largest circle in the illustration, it is therefore the overarching framework “within which staff receive coaching and consultation as well as the opportunity to attend foundation and skill-building workshops.”

D.Choice: receiving coaching and consultation is the overarching framework within which staff have the opportunity to belong to a professional network as well as attend foundation and skill-building workshops.

Key.Rationale: As shown in the illustration, “coaching and consultation” and “foundation and skill-building workshops” occupy smaller circles within the professional-development framework, and thus cannot be the overarching framework.

SubTopics: Boundaries, for which students must edit text to ensure that sentences are conventionally complete.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L11 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice contains punctuation marks.
This choice contains punctuation marks.
No punctuation is needed between the main verb “can identify” and the clause that begins with “which” and functions as the object of the verb.
This choice contains punctuation marks.

SubTopics: Transitions, for which students must determine the most effective transition word or phrase to logically connect information and ideas in a text.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L1 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This transition does not indicate the contrast that sets up the resistance to the Slow Food movement discussed in the passage.
This transition does not indicate the contrast that sets up the resistance to the Slow Food movement discussed in the passage.

The transition “however” indicates that a contrast or difference will follow. In this sentence two types of diners are being contrasted: “on-the-go eaters” and those who value “regional foods” and “culture built on cooking and long meals.”
This transition does not indicate the contrast that sets up the resistance to the Slow Food movement discussed in the passage.

SubTopics: Boundaries, for which students must edit text to ensure that sentences are conventionally complete.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L2 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: A comma is needed to separate the introductory infinitive phrase beginning with “to counter” from the independent main clause of the sentence beginning with “a cohort.”
A semicolon is used in this context between two independent clauses.
A colon is used before a list or to set off an important idea.
The infinitive phrase beginning with “to counter” is not a complete sentence.

SubTopics: Rhetorical Synthesis, for which students must strategically integrate provided information and ideas on a topic to form an effective sentence achieving a specified rhetorical aim.
Content: Refer to location L3 of the passage and think about the passage as a whole.
At this point, the writer is considering adding the following sentence.
:ibox:The group's philosophy was connected to the tale of the hare and the tortoise, in which the tortoise wins the race.
Should the writer make this addition here?

A.Choice: Yes, because it explains the primary belief that led to the development of the Slow Food movement.

Key.Rationale: The sentence is irrelevant without further explanation.

B.Choice: Yes, because it reinforces a claim that the writer makes earlier in the paragraph.

Key.Rationale: The sentence is irrelevant without further explanation.

C.Choice: No, because it blurs the paragraph's focus by introducing a new idea that is not clearly explained.

Key.Rationale: The sentence should not be added because the fact that the Slow Food movement's philosophy “was connected to the tale of the hare and the tortoise” blurs the focus of the paragraph, which is the contrast between two attitudes toward eating. The idea is also not clearly explained.

D.Choice: No, because it distracts from the paragraph's emphasis on the Slow Food movement's origins and beliefs.

Key.Rationale: The paragraph doesn't emphasize the “Slow Food movement's origins and beliefs.”

SubTopics: Form, Structure, and Sense, for which students must edit text to conform to conventional usage (e.g., agreement, verb tense/aspect).
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L4 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice, which is a past perfect tense verb, provides a transition that does not indicate the true relationship of shared responsibility between employees and employers.
This choice, which is a present tense verb, provides a transition that does not indicate the true relationship of shared responsibility between employees and employers.
This choice, which is a future tense verb, provides a transition that does not indicate the true relationship of shared responsibility between employees and employers.
The auxiliary verb “has” correctly indicates that the Slow Food movement's opposition to fast food's standardization of taste is ongoing.

SubTopics: Boundaries, for which students must edit text to ensure that sentences are conventionally complete.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L5 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: Commas are needed to set off the nonrestrictive phrase.

B.Choice: factors, such as altitude and weather,

Key.Rationale: The comma, which is necessary to set off information that may be informative but is not necessary for understanding the sentence, is placed correctly after the noun “factors” and after the noun “weather.”

C.Choice: factors such as, altitude and weather,

Key.Rationale: The first comma is misplaced.

D.Choice: factors, such as altitude and weather

Key.Rationale: There should be a comma after “weather.”

SubTopics: Rhetorical Synthesis, for which students must strategically integrate provided information and ideas on a topic to form an effective sentence achieving a specified rhetorical aim.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L6 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively supports the central point of the paragraph?

Key.Rationale: This choice contains ideas that are not consistent with those in the paragraph. Specifically, it is subjective and mentions flavor quality instead of diversity.

B.Choice: the public would not be interested in learning about traditional foods.

Key.Rationale: This choice contains ideas that are not consistent with those in the paragraph. Specifically, it addresses learning about traditional food.

C.Choice: people would not be able to determine how a particular food was made.

Key.Rationale: This choice contains ideas that are not consistent with those in the paragraph. Specifically, it addresses how food is made.

D.Choice: consumers would lose this diversity of flavors.

Key.Rationale: This choice most effectively supports the central point of the paragraph — the factors that influence the diversity of food flavors.

SubTopics: Form, Structure, and Sense, for which students must edit text to conform to conventional usage (e.g., agreement, verb tense/aspect).
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L7 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: “Their” is a plural possessive pronoun, which cannot be used with a singular noun.
The pronoun “there” refers to a place or is used to introduce a clause, and it is not possessive.
The singular possessive pronoun “its” refers correctly to the singular noun “movement.”
“It's” is a contraction for “it is,” not a possessive pronoun, and does not make sense in the sentence.

SubTopics: Rhetorical Synthesis, for which students must strategically integrate provided information and ideas on a topic to form an effective sentence achieving a specified rhetorical aim.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L8 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice is wordy and contains unnecessary repetition. “Lots of time” and “long meals” are the same.

B.Choice: leisurely meals with friends and family.

Key.Rationale: “Leisurely meals with friends and family” is clear and concise and eliminates unnecessary repetition.

C.Choice: eating slowly and in the company of loved ones such as friends and family.

Key.Rationale: This choice is wordy and contains unnecessary repetition. “Loved ones such as friends and family” is redundant.

D.Choice: joining friends as well as family for time-consuming meals.

Key.Rationale: “Time-consuming meals” has a negative connotation, which is not consistent with the Slow Food movement's belief that long, leisurely meals are beneficial.

SubTopics: Form, Structure, and Sense, for which students must edit text to conform to conventional usage (e.g., agreement, verb tense/aspect).
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L9 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice contains a synonym for “drew,” but refers to drawing as an artistic exercise. This choice does not work within the context of the sentence, since drawing here means enticing or attracting.

This choice contains a synonym for “drew,” but refers to drawing as an artistic exercise. This choice does not work within the context of the sentence, since drawing here means enticing or attracting.
“Drew criticism” is an idiomatic phrase meaning “caused criticism to flow forth,” which fits in the context of the sentence.

This choice contains a synonym for “drew,” but refers to drawing as an artistic exercise. This choice does not work within the context of the sentence, since drawing here means enticing or attracting.

SubTopics: Form, Structure, and Sense, for which students must edit text to conform to conventional usage (e.g., agreement, verb tense/aspect).
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L10 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice contains a question mark.

B.Choice: adequately and affordably can feed the world?

Key.Rationale: This choice contains a question mark.

C.Choice: can adequately and affordably feed the world.

Key.Rationale: The sentence contains an indirect question, which does not take a question mark.

D.Choice: adequately and affordably can feed the world.

Key.Rationale: The word order is confusing.

SubTopics: Transitions, for which students must determine the most effective transition word or phrase to logically connect information and ideas in a text.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L11 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This option does not show the true relationship between the sentences. “In short” means that a summary will follow.

This option does not show the true relationship between the sentences. “Nonetheless” means that in spite of the fact that something has been stated as being a certain way, an exception or contrasting statement will follow.

The prepositional phrase “to these ends” is used correctly as a transition to show that the three beliefs identified in the previous sentence cause the action (supporting small-scale producers) in the sentence that the prepositional phrase introduces.
This option does not show the true relationship between the sentences. “By the same token” indicates that a similar idea will follow.

SubTopics: Boundaries, for which students must edit text to ensure that sentences are conventionally complete.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L1 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: The comma is placed correctly after “declared” to set off the headline that follows.

B.Choice: headline in the New York Times, declared

Key.Rationale: This choice contains a misplaced comma.

C.Choice: headline, in the New York Times declared,

Key.Rationale: This choice contains a misplaced comma. Additionally, the inclusion of a second comma suggests incorrectly that the information between the commas could be eliminated without changing the meaning of the sentence.

D.Choice: headline, in the New York Times, declared

Key.Rationale: This choice contains a misplaced comma. Additionally, the inclusion of a second comma suggests incorrectly that the information between the commas could be eliminated without changing the meaning of the sentence.

SubTopics: Rhetorical Synthesis, for which students must strategically integrate provided information and ideas on a topic to form an effective sentence achieving a specified rhetorical aim.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L2 of the passage.
The writer wants to add a supporting detail to indicate that the story was widely reported. Which revision best accomplishes this goal?

Key.Rationale: This choice identifies only one news source.

B.Choice: Other newspapers also ran stories claiming that the broadcast had incited mass hysteria.

Key.Rationale: This choice clearly says that “other newspapers also ran stories claiming that the broadcast had incited mass hysteria,” which suggests that the story was widely reported.

C.Choice: In 2013, many newspapers and magazines featured articles about the seventy‑fifth anniversary of the broadcast.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not relevant to the paragraph.

D.Choice: The Times was then and is now one of the United States' most popular news sources.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not relevant to the paragraph.

SubTopics: Form, Structure, and Sense, for which students must edit text to conform to conventional usage (e.g., agreement, verb tense/aspect).
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L3 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice changes the meaning of the sentence. A broadcast can't “have” people. This choice would also require a comma before “who feared” to make it grammatically correct.
The relative pronoun “that” isn't used to begin clauses describing people.
The participle “fearing” clearly describes the people who thought that Martians had invaded Earth and places the focus on “fear.”
The infinitive “to fear” doesn't make sense in the sentence.

SubTopics: Form, Structure, and Sense, for which students must edit text to conform to conventional usage (e.g., agreement, verb tense/aspect).
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L4 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice is not idiomatic.
This choice is not idiomatic.
This choice is not idiomatic.
“Go so far as to” is an idiomatic expression meaning “proceed to the point of doing something.”

SubTopics: Transitions, for which students must determine the most effective transition word or phrase to logically connect information and ideas in a text.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L5 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not show the true relationship between the sentences. The previous sentence makes a statement that the following sentence expands upon.
This choice does not show the true relationship between the sentences. The previous sentence makes a statement that the following sentence expands upon.
The prepositional phrase “in the article” is used correctly to link the article mentioned in the previous sentence to a statement that was made in the article.
This choice does not show the true relationship between the sentences. The previous sentence makes a statement that the following sentence expands upon.

SubTopics: Rhetorical Synthesis, for which students must strategically integrate provided information and ideas on a topic to form an effective sentence achieving a specified rhetorical aim.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L6 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively combines the sentences at the emphasized portion?

A.Choice: profits, which is what the newspaper industry tried to do when it portrayed

Key.Rationale: This choice includes unnecessary words that do not add meaning to the sentence.

B.Choice: profits, by which the newspaper industry portrayed

Key.Rationale: This choice includes unnecessary words that do not add meaning to the sentence.

C.Choice: profits and tried to do this by portraying

Key.Rationale: The conjunction “and” is unnecessary and confusing.
The prepositional phrase “by portraying the new medium as irresponsible” clearly and concisely tells how the newspaper industry “sought to discredit the newly emerging technology of radio.”

SubTopics: Rhetorical Synthesis, for which students must strategically integrate provided information and ideas on a topic to form an effective sentence achieving a specified rhetorical aim.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L7 of the passage.
Which revision best establishes the main idea of the paragraph?

Key.Rationale: This choice is too specific since the paragraph doesn't evaluate the strength of Pooley and Socolow's argument.

B.Choice: but evidence does suggest that reports of panic have been overblown.

Key.Rationale: It best establishes the main idea of the paragraph by focusing on the overblown reports of panic. The paragraph lists various pieces of evidence to support the claim that reports were exaggerated; for instance, “a mere 2 percent of households had tuned in to the broadcast” and the validity of “an oft- cited report” is called into question.

C.Choice: yet Pooley and Socolow maintain that the newspaper industry intentionally distorted the story.

Key.Rationale: This choice is too specific since the paragraph doesn't focus on Pooley and Socolow's insistence on newspapers' distortions.

D.Choice: making it difficult to determine what really happened in 1938.

Key.Rationale: This choice is too general and doesn't focus on a topic.

SubTopics: Form, Structure, and Sense, for which students must edit text to conform to conventional usage (e.g., agreement, verb tense/aspect).
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L8 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: “Fewer” is an adjective that is used with things that can be counted and therefore is used correctly in this sentence to describe “people.” “Far” is an adverb that describes the adjective “fewer” and is used to indicate the extent to which the number of people listening to the broadcast differed from a million.
The adjective “less” is used when describing things that cannot be counted.
The adjective “less” is used when describing things that cannot be counted. This choice uses “then” and not the appropriate comparison preposition “than.”
This choice uses “then” and not the appropriate comparison preposition “than.”

SubTopics: Transitions, for which students must determine the most effective transition word or phrase to logically connect information and ideas in a text.
Content: Refer to location L9 of the passage and think about the passage as a whole.
To make this paragraph most logical, sentence 4 should be placed

Key.Rationale: It would be illogical and confusing to place sentence 4 after sentence 3.
It would be illogical and confusing to place sentence 4 after sentence 2.
It would be illogical and confusing to place sentence 4 after sentence 5.

Sentence 4 is most logically placed after sentence 7 because sentence 7 implies that the words used in the survey were used synonymously, even though the words convey different levels of reaction. Sentence 4 supports this idea with further explanation.

SubTopics: Boundaries, for which students must edit text to ensure that sentences are conventionally complete.
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L10 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: Without a comma, the resulting restrictive clause changes the meaning of the sentence.
The pronoun “they” introduces an independent clause and provides another, unnecessary subject for the sentence.

The pronoun “some” is used correctly as the subject of the independent clause. The comma after “some” is needed to set off the nonrestrictive clause (“influenced by the sensationalized news coverage afterward”) that follows it.
A comma is needed to set off the nonrestrictive clause.

SubTopics: Form, Structure, and Sense, for which students must edit text to conform to conventional usage (e.g., agreement, verb tense/aspect).
Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L11 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively signals the comparison the writer is making between the two groups mentioned?

Key.Rationale: “Not unlike,” which means the same as “like,” most effectively signals the similarity between the two groups mentioned by the researchers.
This choice indicates difference instead of similarity.
This choice indicates difference instead of similarity.
This choice indicates difference instead of similarity.
